articles.headline: Slow Rise in Consumer Prices May Stymie the Fed
articles.snippet: The slow pace of inflation means Americans are experiencing less erosion in the value of their paychecks at a time when wages, too, are rising slowly. But it is also evidence the recovery is incomplete.
articles.abstract: The slow pace of inflation means Americans are experiencing less erosion in the value of their paychecks at a time when wages, too, are rising slowly. But it is also evidence the recovery is incomplete.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Consumer prices in the United States are rising at the slowest pace during a period of economic growth in the last half-century, a trend that could delay the Federal Reserve’s retreat from its stimulus campaign.

articles.headline: A French Town Linked to Jihad Asks Itself Why
articles.snippet: In the wake of attacks in Paris, the southern town of Lunel, population 25,700, is trying to fathom how it became a source of recruits for fighting in Syria.
articles.abstract: In the wake of attacks in Paris, the southern town of Lunel, population 25,700, is trying to fathom how it became a source of recruits for fighting in Syria.
articles.lead_paragraph: LUNEL, France — When this picturesque southern French town of just 25,700 people first learned late last year that six local Muslims had been killed fighting for Islam in Syria, accounting for 10 percent of the total number of French killed there, the right-wing mayor quietly asked the head of the local mosque for help.

articles.headline: Supreme Court to Decide Marriage Rights for Gay Couples Nationwide
articles.snippet: The court, after declining to take up the issue in October, is now likely to resolve one of the great civil rights questions of the age before its current term ends in June.
articles.abstract: The court, after declining to take up the issue in October, is now likely to resolve one of the great civil rights questions of the age before its current term ends in June.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Friday agreed to decide whether all 50 states must allow gay and lesbian couples to marry, positioning it to resolve one of the great civil rights questions in a generation before its current term ends in June.

articles.headline: Superyachts to the Rescue
articles.snippet: In a remarkable economic comeback, La Ciotat has become Europe’s largest yacht-maintenance and refitting seaport.
articles.abstract: In a remarkable economic comeback, La Ciotat has become Europe’s largest yacht-maintenance and refitting seaport.
articles.lead_paragraph: LA CIOTAT, France — After scuba divers checked the supporting mounts, a massive submerged boat elevator slowly raised the 661-ton, 51-meter-long yacht M/Y Sky clear of the Mediterranean, gradually revealing its black matte hull.

articles.headline: Slippery Tips on Annuities From a Life Coach
articles.snippet: Tony Robbins’s best-selling new book speaks highly of a certain type of annuity, but there may be less there than meets the eye.
articles.abstract: Tony Robbins’s best-selling new book speaks highly of a certain type of annuity, but there may be less there than meets the eye.
articles.lead_paragraph: By Page 418 of Tony Robbins’s new book “Money: Master the Game,” which promises on the cover that its seven steps to financial freedom will be “simple,” I was sort of ready to put it down.

articles.headline: Travel to Cuba Eases, but Airlines Will Miss Initial Rush
articles.snippet: The United States has relaxed some restrictions on going there, but letting carriers set up regular flights is another matter.
articles.abstract: The United States has relaxed some restrictions on going there, but letting carriers set up regular flights is another matter.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Obama administration this week lifted some travel and trade restrictions on Americans traveling to Cuba, but commercial airlines will not be flocking to Havana for at least another year, experts say.

articles.headline: ‘No, No, No, No’ Becomes Maybe for Ann Romney
articles.snippet: After telling The Los Angeles Times last year that she and her family were done with her husband’s political career, Ann Romney has returned to courting supporters.
articles.abstract: After telling The Los Angeles Times last year that she and her family were done with her husband’s political career, Ann Romney has returned to courting supporters.
articles.lead_paragraph: In an interview last fall, Ann Romney made clear that her husband’s political career — and his family’s support for it — were over.

articles.headline: Patriot Act Idea Rises in France, and Is Ridiculed
articles.snippet: After the shootings in Paris last week, France finds itself grappling with how to fight terrorism while protecting civil liberties — a question the United States has confronted since 9/11.
articles.abstract: After the shootings in Paris last week, France finds itself grappling with how to fight terrorism while protecting civil liberties — a question the United States has confronted since 9/11.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The arrests came quickly after the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks. There was the Muslim man suspected of making anti-American statements. The Middle Eastern grocer, whose shop, a tipster said, had more clerks than it needed. Soon hundreds of men, mostly Muslims, were in American jails on immigration charges, suspected of being involved in the attacks.
articles.byline: By Matt Apuzzo and Steven Erlanger

articles.headline: Green-Energy Inspiration Off the Coast of Denmark
articles.snippet: Residents of islands off Maine’s coast seek to draw on the experiences of the Danish island Samso in an effort to explore alternative sources of light and heat.
articles.abstract: Residents of islands off Maine’s coast seek to draw on the experiences of the Danish island Samso in an effort to explore alternative sources of light and heat.
articles.lead_paragraph: Before dawn one morning in October, a handful of Americans gathered at a lonely pier on Samso, a small Danish island about four hours from Copenhagen. Bundled in layers of fleece and wool, the Americans, mostly from islands off the Maine coast, had come to get a closer look at a wind farm — 10 mighty turbines spinning in the Kattegat strait — that has helped make Samso a symbol for a greener future, one powered entirely by renewable energy.

articles.headline: What’s So Bad About Cheap Oil?
articles.snippet: The stock market is treating lower prices as bad news even though they will help consumers, many of the nation’s businesses and the economy.
articles.abstract: The stock market is treating lower prices as bad news even though they will help consumers, many of the nation’s businesses and the economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: The sharp drop in oil prices will benefit American consumers, many of the nation’s businesses and the economy as a whole. So why are stock market investors behaving as though oil under $50 a barrel and gasoline prices hovering around $2 a gallon are bad news?

articles.headline: From Amateur to Ruthless Jihadist in France
articles.snippet: Documents reveal how Chérif Kouachi became a professional jihadist virtually under the noses of the French authorities and, with his brother, Saïd, carried out the attack on Charlie Hebdo.
articles.abstract: Documents reveal how Chérif Kouachi became a professional jihadist virtually under the noses of the French authorities and, with his brother, Saïd, carried out the attack on Charlie Hebdo.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — In the year after the United States’ invasion of Iraq, a 22-year-old pizza delivery man here couldn’t take it anymore. Sickened by images of American soldiers humiliating Muslims at the Abu Ghraib prison, he made plans to go fight United States forces. He studied a virtual AK-47 on a website. Then he took lessons from a man, using a hand-drawn picture of a gun.
articles.byline: By Rukmini Callimachi and Jim Yardley

articles.headline: Decoding the Paradox of Rising Cable Stocks
articles.snippet: Why, despite President Obama’s moves toward greater regulation of Internet providers, cable companies’ share prices have continued to go up.
articles.abstract: Why, despite President Obama’s moves toward greater regulation of Internet providers, cable companies’ share prices have continued to go up.
articles.lead_paragraph: The stock market is often an early indicator of major developments in finance, the economy and geopolitics. But sometimes that collective wisdom generates signals so difficult to decipher that they seem contradictory.

articles.headline: Odd Byproduct of Legal Marijuana: Homes That Blow Up
articles.snippet: Cities are trying to clamp down as some amateur alchemists who turn their kitchens and basements into labs end up blowing up their homes while using flammable chemicals to extract potent drops of a marijuana concentrate.
articles.abstract: Cities are trying to clamp down as some amateur alchemists who turn their kitchens and basements into labs end up blowing up their homes while using flammable chemicals to extract potent drops of a marijuana concentrate.
articles.lead_paragraph: DENVER — When Colorado legalized marijuana two years ago, nobody was quite ready for the problem of exploding houses.

articles.headline: The Bushes, as Distinct and Alike as Brothers Can Be
articles.snippet: While loving and supportive of each other, George W. and Jeb Bush do not talk that often, according to family intimates, and they travel in different circles.
articles.abstract: While loving and supportive of each other, George W. and Jeb Bush do not talk that often, according to family intimates, and they travel in different circles.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — One day last fall, former President George W. Bush called Mel Sembler, a Republican donor from Florida who had served as his ambassador to Italy. Mr. Sembler had just had a pacemaker implanted into his chest, and his wife had also recently had surgery. Mr. Bush wanted to check on how they were faring.

articles.headline: Obama Will Seek to Raise Taxes on Wealthy to Finance Cuts for Middle Class
articles.snippet: President Obama will use his State of the Union address Tuesday to call on Congress to raise taxes and fees on the wealthiest taxpayers to finance the tax cuts, administration officials said on Saturday.
articles.abstract: President Obama will use his State of the Union address Tuesday to call on Congress to raise taxes and fees on the wealthiest taxpayers to finance the tax cuts, administration officials said on Saturday.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama will use his State of the Union address to call on Congress to raise taxes and fees on the wealthiest taxpayers and the largest financial firms to finance an array of tax cuts for the middle class, pressing to reshape the tax code to help working families, administration officials said on Saturday.

articles.headline: Microsoft Looks to Windows 10 for a Jolt in the Mobile Realm
articles.snippet: Windows 10 is the biggest effort yet by Satya Nadella, Microsoft’s new chief, who has been able to lift the company’s stock to a nearly 15-year high.
articles.abstract: Windows 10 is the biggest effort yet by Satya Nadella, Microsoft’s new chief, who has been able to lift the company’s stock to a nearly 15-year high.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Optimism is a renewable resource at Microsoft.

articles.headline: Why the Oscars’ Omission of ‘Selma’ Matters
articles.snippet: In general, the film academy and the industry it mirrors manage diversity the same way that corporate America does, by ticking off boxes.
articles.abstract: In general, the film academy and the industry it mirrors manage diversity the same way that corporate America does, by ticking off boxes.
articles.lead_paragraph: Monday is Martin Luther King Jr. Day and given the context, it is an interesting moment to ask whether it really matters that the motion picture academy failed to nominate the black director and the black lead actor of “Selma,” the King biopic, for Oscars.

articles.headline: Nickelodeon Remixes Its Sitcom Formula to Adapt to Children’s Media Consumption
articles.snippet: In an effort to counter ratings declines and children’s changing tastes, the network has introduced shows that have more nuance and sophistication.
articles.abstract: In an effort to counter ratings declines and children’s changing tastes, the network has introduced shows that have more nuance and sophistication.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Buffoonish parents. Voice-of-reason best friend. Laugh track. Extra-bright lighting. Nifty girl’s bedroom with window seat.

articles.headline: Gay Marriage Case Offers G.O.P. Political Cover
articles.snippet: If the Supreme Court resolves the issue as expected, it could largely neutralize a debate that a majority of Americans believe Republicans are on the wrong side of.
articles.abstract: If the Supreme Court resolves the issue as expected, it could largely neutralize a debate that a majority of Americans believe Republicans are on the wrong side of.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The news Friday that the Supreme Court will rule on same-sex marriage brought elation from gays and lesbians who are hopeful the justices will grant them the constitutional protections they have long sought.
articles.byline: By Jeremy W. Peters and Jonathan Martin

articles.headline: Riding High, Biotech Firms Remain Wary
articles.snippet: Soaring stock prices and major advances in fighting diseases have some saying the industry has turned a corner and others watching for a bursting bubble.
articles.abstract: Soaring stock prices and major advances in fighting diseases have some saying the industry has turned a corner and others watching for a bursting bubble.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The biotechnology industry tends to be overshadowed by the razzle-dazzle of high-tech companies like Apple, Facebook and Google, particularly in the Bay Area.

articles.headline: N.S.A. Breached North Korean Networks Before Sony Attack, Officials Say
articles.snippet: Evidence gathered by software hidden by the N.S.A. to monitor North Korean activities proved critical in persuading President Obama to accuse the government of ordering the cyberattack on Sony, officials said.
articles.abstract: Evidence gathered by software hidden by the N.S.A. to monitor North Korean activities proved critical in persuading President Obama to accuse the government of ordering the cyberattack on Sony, officials said.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The trail that led American officials to blame North Korea for the destructive cyberattack on Sony Pictures Entertainment in November winds back to 2010, when the National Security Agency scrambled to break into the computer systems of a country considered one of the most impenetrable targets on earth.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and Martin Fackler

articles.headline: Cubans Convicted in the U.S. Face New Fears of Deportation
articles.snippet: A longstanding policy of permitting Cubans with criminal convictions to remain in the United States is suddenly on shakier ground.
articles.abstract: A longstanding policy of permitting Cubans with criminal convictions to remain in the United States is suddenly on shakier ground.
articles.lead_paragraph: MIAMI — For Amaury Villa, who arrived here from Cuba more than 15 years ago and became a permanent resident, pleading guilty in 2012 to federal charges that he sold stolen prescription drugs was a difficult choice. But there was one positive aspect: Unlike most foreign citizens convicted of serious crimes, Mr. Villa stood next to no chance of being deported back to his home country.
articles.byline: By Lizette Alvarez and Kristin Hussey

articles.headline: Banking Start-Ups Adopt New Tools for Lending
articles.snippet: New software is expected to sharpen assessments of creditworthiness, but even proponents acknowledge the potential for inadvertent discrimination.
articles.abstract: New software is expected to sharpen assessments of creditworthiness, but even proponents acknowledge the potential for inadvertent discrimination.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — When bankers of the future decide whether to make a loan, they may look to see if potential customers use only capital letters when filling out forms, or at the amount of time they spend online reading terms and conditions — and not so much at credit history.

articles.headline: Insurance via Internet Is Squeezing Agents
articles.snippet: Technology start-ups with websites that sell many types of insurance and promise savings with comparison shopping are putting pressure on insurance agents, who collect commissions.
articles.abstract: Technology start-ups with websites that sell many types of insurance and promise savings with comparison shopping are putting pressure on insurance agents, who collect commissions.
articles.lead_paragraph: To the list of jobs threatened by the Internet, add one more: insurance agent.

articles.headline: In Colorado, Disparity in Health Plan Prices Underscores Ambitions, and Limits, of Affordable Care Act
articles.snippet: At first glance, Colorado seems to be one of the federal law’s clearest success stories. But zoom in closer, and it is clear that a kind of pricing pandemonium is underway.
articles.abstract: At first glance, Colorado seems to be one of the federal law’s clearest success stories. But zoom in closer, and it is clear that a kind of pricing pandemonium is underway.
articles.lead_paragraph: At first glance, Colorado would seem to be one of the federal health law’s clearest success stories, offering nearly 200 plans and average premiums nearly unchanged in the coming year.
articles.byline: By Reed Abelson and Agustin Armendariz
